Tate degeneration and DVRs

Jul 14, 2021

I seem to keep failing consistently at posting consistently… So let me try again to start posting (semi-)regularly. Last time, I said that we will explore what happens with quantization in characteristic p. I didn’t end up making any posts, mostly because I had to take Harvard’s qualifying exams at the end of August, and then I got distracted once the semester began. I guess I’ve now finished a full year of grad school, but it doesn’t quite feel real. I’m very much looking forward to the fall (it’s been announced that the math department is reopening on Aug 16th!). In any case, if you are interested in quantization in characteristic $p$, check out the seminar that I’m running this summer; I’m posting notes, which contain more details than I usually write in these posts.

I came across this paper yesterday, which proves the following theorem. Fix a DVR $R$ with uniformizer $\pi$, and let $K = R[1/\pi]$. Let $\dX \to \spf(R)$ be a smooth proper formal scheme, and let $W(k)$ be the ring of Witt vectors of the residue field $k$ of $R$. Let $g(t)\in W(k)\pw{t}$ be an Eisenstein polynomial (obtained as the minimal polynomial of the uniformizer $\pi$). Let $e$ denote the ramification index of $R$. If $\dX$ lifts to $W(k)\pw{t}/g^2$, and

$\dim_{R}(\dX) + 1 < \frac{p-1}{e},$

then the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence for $\dX$ degenerates at the $E_1$-page, and there are no extensions on the $E_\infty$-page.

We will now discuss a homotopical version of this statement. Assume for the remainder of this discussion that $R$ is $\pi$-complete. Let $\cC$ be a smooth and proper $R$-linear stable $\infty$-category. We claim:

Thm: Suppose that $\HH(\cC/R)$ is a projective $R$-module (in the spectral sense). Then the Tate spectral sequence $\hat{\H}^\ast(\CP^\infty; \pi_\ast \HH(\cC/R)) \Rightarrow \pi_\ast \HP(\cC/R)$ degenerates at the $E_2$-page, and there are no extensions on the $E_\infty$-page. In fact, $\HP(\cC/R) \simeq \HH(\cC/R)\otimes_R R^{tS^1}$.

The proof is basically an adaptation of Mathew’s argument: instead of showing that $\HP(\cC/R)$ is free over $R^{tS^1}$, the idea is to prove something about the ``conjugate filtration’’ on $\HP(\cC/R)$. We first need some preliminaries.

Prop: There is an equivalence $\THH(R/\sph_{W(k)}\pw{t}) \simeq R[\Omega S^3]$.

According to this paper, this result is due to Bhatt-Lurie-Scholze. It can be proved (see Remark 10 of these notes) by writing $R$ as the Thom spectrum of the map $\Omega^2 S^3 \to \BGL_1(\sph_{W(k)}\pw{t})$ which detects $1+g(t)\in W(k)\pw{t}^\times$. (I found out recently that this sort of result is proved in this paper.)

We now prove an analogue of Proposition 3.9 of Mathew’s paper. We first begin with a calculation, which is an exact analogue of Proposition 3.6 of that paper.

Prop: We have $\pi_\ast \tau_{\leq 2p-2} \THH(W(k)\pw{t}/g^2) \cong W(k)\pw{t,u}/(g^2, u^p)$ with $|u|=2$.

Proof: As in Mathew’s paper, the range we are calculating in is algebraic (i.e., $\sph_{W(k)}\pw{t} \to W(k)\pw{t}$ is an equivalence in dimensions $\leq 2p-4$), and so it suffices to calculate $\HH((W(k)\pw{t}/g^2)/W(k)\pw{t})$. But this is

where all these tensor products are derived. In general, if $B$ is a commutative ring and $x\in B$, then $B/x \otimes_B B/x$ is equivalent to $(B/x)[\epsilon]$ with $|\epsilon|=1$. Then, $B/x \otimes_{(B/x)[\epsilon]} B/x$ is equivalent to $\Gamma_{B/x}[u]$ with $|u|=2$. So we see that

and its $(2p-2)$-truncation is equivalent to $\tau_{2p-2} \THH(W(k)\pw{t}/g^2)$. That gives the proposition.

In the same way, the map $\THH((W(k)\pw{t}/g^2)/\sph_{W(k)}\pw{t}) \to \THH(R/\sph_{W(k)}\pw{t})$ is zero in $\pi_2$ (and hence on $\pi_i$ for $1\leq i\leq 2p-2$). That’s because on $\pi_2$, these are both isomorphic to Hochschild homology relative to $W(k)\pw{t}$. The HKR filtration tells us that, for instance, $\gr^i \HH(R/W(k)\pw{t})$ is $\wedge^i L_{R/W(k)\pw{t}}[i]$. This term is $i$-connective. Now, $L_{R/W(k)\pw{t}} \simeq (g)/(g^2)[1]$, so $\wedge^i L_{R/W(k)\pw{t}}[i] \cong R[2i]$. In particular, the only contribution to $\pi_2 \HH(R/W(k)\pw{t})$ is $\pi_1 L_{R/W(k)\pw{t}}$. Similarly for $\THH(W(k)\pw{t}/g^2)$. So the map on $\pi_2$ is induced by $\pi_1$ of the canonical map $L_{(W(k)\pw{t}/g^2)/W(k)\pw{t}} \to L_{R/W(k)\pw{t}}$. But this map is just $(g^2)/(g^4)[1] \to (g)/(g^2)[1]$, and so is zero.
